newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel Treasury director-general to leave March 31.
newsitem.headline: Israel Treasury director-general to leave March 31.

text.p: Israel's Finance Ministry director-general David Brodet will be leaving his post March 31 to be replaced by an official at the country's lottery organisation.

Shmuel Slavin, Brodet's designated successor, was former prime minster Yitzhak Shamir's economics adviser and is an activist in the ruling Likud party. He has been a deputy managing director at Mifal Hapayis, the state lottery organisation, since 1994.
Brodet served in senior Treasury positions under two Likud governments and one Labour government. He had been budget director since 1991 and moved up to director-general in 1995.
He has refused to comment on his plans after leaving the Treasury.

As director-general, Brodet chaired a number of key committees, among them the panel that recommended forcing the commercial banks to reduce their stakes in non-bank companies. He also led the Israeli delegation to economic negotiations with the Palestinians as part of the Oslo peace accords.
Brodet presided at the Treasury as the government's deficit ballooned in 1996. But he stayed on to help achieve the 1997 budget cuts aimed at reining in overspending this year.
